1em!important;width:auto!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk button:hover{background-color:#fff!important;border-color:#eb6500!important;color:#2e2e2e!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk         window.__PRELOADED_STATE__ = {"abstracts":{"content":[{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st095"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Graphical abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$$":[{"$":{"role":"http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4","xmlns:xlink":true,"href":"pii:S0021979720313679/ga1","id":"lk005","locator":"ga1"},"#name":"link"}],"$":{"id":"f0035"},"#name":"figure"}],"#name":"display"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp005"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as005"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab005","lang":"en","class":"graphical"},"#name":"abstract"},{"$$":[{"$":{"id":"st100"},"#name":"section-title","_":"Abstract"},{"$$":[{"$$":[{"#name":"__text__","_":"Increasing the electrochemical performance of electrode materials in sodium ion batteries (NIBs) remains a major challenge. Here, a combined experimental and theoretical investigation on the modification induced by Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"S"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" embedded in a heteroatom-doped 3D carbon matrix (CM) for efficient anodes in NIBs is presented. The structural and chemical characterization demonstrates the successful doping of 3D CM with S and Sb atoms. When evaluated as anode materials for NIBs, the heteroatom-doped nanocomposites delivered a better cycling stability and superior rate capability than those of undoped Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"S"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"/CM anodes. Doping the carbon substrate by heteroatoms improved the adsorption of Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"S"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" on the matrix and allowed for ionic/covalent attraction with the Sb"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"S"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"3"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" nanoparticle, respectively. Such results could be used to model the stabilty of the composite architectures observed in the experiment, for superior cycling stability."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp010"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as010"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab010","lang":"en","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979720313679/ga1/DOWNSAMPLED/image/jpeg/e7410027a6abc61a670383dc0f071301/ga1.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"22538","pixel-height":"200","pixel-width":"312","attachment-type":"IMAGE-DOWNSAMPLED"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1.sml","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979720313679/ga1/THUMBNAIL/image/gif/884ff83baca683e0663048f176f3ccc0/ga1.sml","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.sml","extension":"sml","filesize":"11464","pixel-height":"140","pixel-width":"219","attachment-type":"IMAGE-THUMBNAIL"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1_lrg.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979720313679/ga1/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/80aa49c283900d47e372ec21a6e0e24f/ga1_lrg.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1_lrg.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"130769","pixel-height":"886","pixel-width":"1384","attachment-type":"IMAGE-HIGH-RES"}]},"accessbarConfig":{"fallback":false,"id":"accessbar","version":"0.0.1","analytics":{"location":"accessbar","eventName":"ctaImpression"},"label":{},"ariaLabel":{"accessbar":"Download publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. class="PageDivider"></div></div></div></div><article class="col-lg-12 col-md-16 pad-left pad-right u-padding-s-top" lang="en"><div class="Publication" id="publication"><div class="publication-brand id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2020.10.044" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2020.10.044</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp010"><span><span>Increasing the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode materials</a><span> in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a> (NIBs) remains a major challenge. Here, a combined experimental and theoretical investigation on the modification induced by Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span> embedded in a heteroatom-doped 3D carbon matrix (CM) for efficient anodes in NIBs is presented. The structural and <a href="/topics/engineering/chemical-characterization" title="Learn more about chemical characterization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemical characterization</a><span> demonstrates the successful doping of 3D CM with S and Sb atoms. When evaluated as <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> for NIBs, the heteroatom-doped </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/nanocomposite" title="Learn more about nanocomposites from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanocomposites</a> delivered a better cycling stability and superior rate capability than those of undoped Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/CM anodes. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/first-principle" title="Learn more about First principle calculations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">First principle calculations</a><span> were used at the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about Density Functional Theory from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Density Functional Theory</a> level to systematically study the Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/heteroatom doped-CM composites, as NIBs anodes. Doping the carbon substrate by heteroatoms improved the adsorption of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> on the matrix and allowed for ionic/covalent attraction with the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticle</a>, respectively. Such results could be used to model the stabilty of the composite architectures observed in the experiment, for superior cycling stability.</span></div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (128KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (128KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S002197972031362X"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979720313680"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Energy storage</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Na-ion battery</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>DFT</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Heteroatom doping</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st005" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">Given the modern societies are highly dependent on electricity consumption, global energy demand is likely to continue to increase annually compared to previous decades. As a result, the search for affordable and reliable non-fossil energy sources is crucial to ensure a global energy access <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a><span><span>. <a href="/topics/chemistry/renewable-energy-source" title="Learn more about Renewable energy sources from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Renewable energy sources</a><span> combined with <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-technology" title="Learn more about energy storage technologies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage technologies</a> became attractive as sustainable alternatives. Nowadays, </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lithium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about lithium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lithium ion batteries</a> (LIBs) dominate the energy storage market due to their high-power density and cycle lifetime </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>. In this respect, the limited Li resources, safety and thermal concerns of LIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a><span> motivate the investigation of viable alternative battery storage solutions. <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about Sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Sodium ion batteries</a><span> (NIBs) have recently emerged as a promising candidate for <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-system" title="Learn more about energy storage systems from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage systems</a> due to the relative natural abundance and low cost of Na </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a><span>. Although the energy storage mechanism in NIBs is similar to that of LIBs, the large <a href="/topics/engineering/ionic-radius" title="Learn more about ionic radius from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic radius</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> ion modifies the interaction with the host material and becomes an important aspect to consider. The <a href="/topics/engineering/interlayer-distance" title="Learn more about interlayer distance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interlayer distance</a> of graphite, which is suitable for LIBs, leads to a mismatch for Na</span><sup>+</sup> ion insertion/extraction mechanisms in NIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span>. Hard carbons and carbons doped with different heteroatoms have been implemented as effective strategies to further enhance the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of carbon-based anodes in NIBs </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. The introduction of heteroatoms such as N, S, P, F and B <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a><span>, into the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a> promotes additional reaction sites and facilitates the Na</span><sup>+</sup> transport across the graphitic layers. For instance, Huang et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a> reported a reversible specific capacity of 357 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span><span><span> after 200 cycles using nitrogen-doped <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a> coating on a </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/3d-graphene" title="Learn more about 3D graphene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">3D graphene</a> framework as anode for NIBs. They suggested that the effect of N-doped carbon framework on the electrochemical performance can be ascribed to the abundant sites for </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> storage and the enhancement of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrode-kinetics" title="Learn more about electrode kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode kinetics</a>. Since sulfur is an electrochemical active element for Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> and Li<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">batteries</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, Li et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a><span> synthesized an anode consisting of sulfur-doped <a href="/topics/engineering/disordered-carbon" title="Learn more about disordered carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disordered carbon</a><span> via one-step pyrolytic technique using a mixture of 1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic dianhydride and sulfur. The S-doped <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about carbon anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon anode</a> delivered a reversible capacity of 516 mAh g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.02 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and long cycling stability (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-57-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;gt;</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1000</mn></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.103ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 3058.3 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1056,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="500" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="1001" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-30" x="1501" y="0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">&gt;</mo><mn is="true">1000</mn></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-57"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">&gt;</mo><mn is="true">1000</mn></mrow></math></script></span> cycles). Similarly, S-doping improves the active sites available in carbon for Na<sup>+</sup><span> ion storage, coupled with its enhancement in <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010"><span>Another interesting approach that has been developed in the design of efficient anodes for NIBs is embedding <a href="/topics/engineering/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanostructured materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructured materials</a><span> into carbon matrices. Several nanocomposites based on carbon matrices (CMs) along with <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a> and sulfides, such as Bi</span></span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, Bi<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, SnO<sub>2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, Sb<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a> and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, have been proposed to enhance the anode performance in NIBs. Particularly, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> is considered as a suitable <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> because of its large theoretical capacity (946 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>) by accommodating 12 Na<sup>+</sup> ions per Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> and its superior <a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a><span> relative to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a><span>. NIB fabricated with reduced <a href="/topics/chemistry/graphene-oxide" title="Learn more about graphene oxide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene oxide</a> (RGO), and decorated with Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanorod" title="Learn more about nanorods from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanorods</a> as an anode material, showed a specific capacity of 652 mAh g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 60 cycles, resulting in a capacity retention of 80.3% <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. According to previous reports, the RGO sheets alleviate the volume change during sodiation/desodiation process related to the conversion and alloying reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. Wu et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a> found that after several cycling, anodes based on Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span> nanowires wrapped by <a href="/topics/engineering/graphene-sheet" title="Learn more about graphene sheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene sheets</a> maintained the one-dimensional (1D) morphology, achieving a capacity retention of 73.07%. Such finding was attributed to the graphene sheets ability to accommodate large volume expansion and alleviate the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/pulverization" title="Learn more about pulverization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pulverization</a> of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span> nanowires. Moreover, issues related to the volume changes, and the strong modifications in the chemical bonding of <a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-sulfides" title="Learn more about metal sulfides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal sulfides</a> on the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-nanostructure" title="Learn more about carbon nanostructures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon nanostructures</a>, have been assessed to develop high-performance anodes for energy storage </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. For instance, a strong chemical binding between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and S-doped graphene sheets (SGS) via a S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bonding, exhibited a stable capacity of 83% at 2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 900 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span>. Experimental results combined with <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about density functional theory from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density functional theory</a> (DFT) investigations evidenced that stronger electron coupling of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/SGS ensure a more stable structure producing a better long-cycle performance. Nevertheless, fundamental challenges remain in the impact of the interaction between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and the carbon matrix (CM), and on the electrochemical performance of anode materials for NIBs.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The combination of experiment and DFT calculations <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a><span><span><span> was used to reveal the excellent electrochemical performance of NIBs consisting of Na metal oxides and non-graphitazable carbon as positive and <a href="/topics/engineering/negative-electrode" title="Learn more about negative electrodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">negative electrodes</a>. Graphene effectively improves the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electron-transport" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a><span> properties of hybrid nanocomposites as anode materials for LIBs. However, the advantages of Na vs. <a href="/topics/materials-science/lithium-ion" title="Learn more about Li ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Li ions</a><span> are: (1) Na is lighter than Li and suppresses dendrite formation, (2) its low <a href="/topics/chemistry/adsorption-energy" title="Learn more about adsorption energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">adsorption energy</a><span> and the weak binding <a href="/topics/materials-science/mechanical-strength" title="Learn more about strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">strength</a> in </span></span></span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/two-dimensional-material" title="Learn more about 2D layered materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">2D layered materials</a>, (3) the amount of Na in the Earthâ€™s crust is 28400&nbsp;mg kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>, while the amount of Li stored is only 20&nbsp;mg kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a><span>. Although the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a><span> of LIBs and NIBs is similar, the low cost of Na allows the possibility to change <a href="/topics/chemistry/lithium-ion" title="Learn more about Li ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Li ions</a> in the market for stationary battery storage systems </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>. In a theoretical work, Mukherjee et al.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a><span> performed a plane wave <a href="/topics/chemistry/density-functional-theory-study" title="Learn more about DFT study from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT study</a> with the GGA-PBE functional to investigate the diffusion and the stability of Na and K over blue phosphorene (BP), in which ultrahigh storage and fast diffusion of Na ions were disclosed. In this context, Datta et al. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a> reported a high-capacity anode material for Na-ion battery on defective graphene. A maximum possible capacity of 1450 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was disclosed for Na-ion battery. The performance of NIBs is considered to be highly regulated by the availability of ions to be diffused at the interface, but no atomistic evidence has been given to solve this issue. In this contribution, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> embedded in Sb- and S-doped 3D carbon matrix (Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM nanocomposites, respectively) were evaluated as anodes for NIBs. A combined experimental and theoretical investigation was conducted to elucidate the role of both the <a href="/topics/engineering/interfacial-interaction" title="Learn more about interfacial interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interfacial interaction</a> between Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and CM trough Sb<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C and S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>C bonds in controlling their <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a>, and the capacitive properties of the composite material Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/carbon and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/doped-carbon used as electrode in high performance NIBs.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st010" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental and computational details</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st015" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Preparation of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/heteroatom-doped nanocomposites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><span><span>All the reagents were of analytical grade and used as received. The 3D CM consisting of multi-walled <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carbon-nanotube" title="Learn more about carbon nanotubes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon nanotubes</a> (CNT) and graphene </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about nanoribbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoribbons</a> (GNR) were prepared following our methods previously described </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a><span>. The Sb-CM and S-CM were obtained by dissolving <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-nanotube" title="Learn more about CNT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNT</a> and GNR on mass ratio of 1:1 with 4&nbsp;mmol SbCl</span><sub>3</sub> or Na<sub>2</sub><span>S into 100&nbsp;mL of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a><span> (D.I.), respectively. Then, the black suspension was refluxed for 8&nbsp;h and collected by filtration. The precipitate was washed several times with water and ethanol and then dried in the oven at 60 Â°C for overnight. The resulting powders were ultrasonicated in a 1.0&nbsp;M HCl aqueous solution at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a>. The Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span><span> embedded in 3D CM with and without <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/heteroatom-doping" title="Learn more about heteroatom doping from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heteroatom doping</a> nanocomposites were synthesized by </span><a href="/topics/engineering/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a><span>. Briefly, 50&nbsp;mg of as-obtained CM powders, 15&nbsp;mM <a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony" title="Learn more about antimony from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony</a><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/potassium" title="Learn more about potassium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">potassium</a><span><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/tartrate" title="Learn more about tartrate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tartrate</a> and 30&nbsp;mM </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/thioacetamide" title="Learn more about thioacetamide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thioacetamide</a> were added to 50&nbsp;mL of D.I. water, and magnetically stirred for 1&nbsp;h. The mixture was poured into a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 150 Â°C for 5&nbsp;h in an electric oven. After the reaction was completed, the precipitate was collected by filtration and washed copiously with D.I. water and ethanol. Lastly, the black product was dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 80 </span></span></span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-58-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xB0;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.162ex" height="1.971ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 500.5 848.5" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 1.257ex; margin-bottom: -1.377ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-B0"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Â°</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-58"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Â°</mi></mrow></math></script></span>C.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st020" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025"><span><span><a href="/topics/engineering/field-emission-scanning-electron-microscope" title="Learn more about Field emission scanning electron microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Field emission scanning electron microscope</a><span> (FESEM) images were obtained by a Hitachi S5500 equipped with a Bruker Quantax energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) system. High-resolution <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (HRTEM) images were taken on a JEOL JEM-2010 microscope. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a Rigaku Ultima IV </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a> with a Cu K</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-59-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î±</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-59"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î±</mi></mrow></math></script></span><span> radiation source. <a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about Thermogravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Thermogravimetric analysis</a><span><span> (TGA) was performed by a Netzsch STA 449 Jupiter at <a href="/topics/engineering/rate-of-heating" title="Learn more about heating rates of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heating rates of</a> 10 Â°C/min. </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> were measured using a WITec confocal Raman Alpha 300 attached with a 532&nbsp;nm <a href="/topics/engineering/laser-excitation" title="Learn more about laser excitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">laser excitation</a>. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were carried out in a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha&nbsp;+&nbsp;spectrometer with a monochromatic Al K</span></span></span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-60-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3B1;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.488ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 640.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3B1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î±</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-60"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î±</mi></mrow></math></script></span> source.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030"><span>The working anodes were prepared by pasting on a cooper foil the slurry mixture consisted of 80 wt% active nanocomposites, 10 wt% conducting carbon black and 10 wt% <a href="/topics/chemistry/critical-micelle-concentration" title="Learn more about carboxymethyl cellulose from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carboxymethyl cellulose</a> (CMC) binder in D.I. water. The electrodes were dried overnight in a vacuum oven at 80 Â°C. Subsequently, the electrodes were cut into 15&nbsp;mm in diameter with a mass loading varying from 1.1 to 1.4&nbsp;mg cm</span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span><span>. For <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical analysis</a>, the nanocomposite electrodes were assembled with </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> metal and <a href="/topics/engineering/celgard" title="Learn more about Celgard from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Celgard</a> 2400 separator in CR2032 coin half-cells in an Ar-filled glove box. 1&nbsp;M NaClO</span></span><sub>4</sub><span> in <a href="/topics/chemistry/propene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate with additional 5% fluoroethylene carbonate was used as electrolyte.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a> (CV) and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were performed using a Bio-Logic VMP-3 potenciostat/galvanostat in the potential range of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V (vs Na/Na</span><sup>+</sup><span>) at ambient temperature. Similarly, <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) were carried out using the same test equipment in the frequency range of 100&nbsp;kHz to 10&nbsp;mHz and an AC voltage with an amplitude of 5&nbsp;mV.</span></div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Computational details</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>The calculations were performed within the framework of DFT using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional for the <a href="/topics/chemistry/exchange-correlation-potential" title="Learn more about exchange correlation potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">exchange correlation potential</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, as implemented in the Quantum ESPRESSO <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a><span> computational code. The PBE functional was chosen, since it has been shown to give reasonable results for the <a href="/topics/chemistry/energetics" title="Learn more about energetic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energetic</a> stability of 2D structures </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a><span>. Since it has been stated that the <a href="/topics/chemistry/intermolecular-force" title="Learn more about intermolecular interactions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">intermolecular interactions</a> are strongly ruled by dispersion effects </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, the van der Waals (vdW) contribution was included using the dispersion correction Grimme method (D2) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. The valence electrons of S(3s<sup>2</sup>3p<sup>4</sup>), C(2s<sup>2</sup>2p<sup>2</sup>), Sb(5s<sup>2</sup>5p<sup>3</sup>) and Na(3s<sup>1</sup><span>) were expanded by using a set of plane waves with an energy cut-off of 450&nbsp;eV. The calculation was performed using a <a href="/topics/engineering/supercell" title="Learn more about supercell from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercell</a> containing 5 </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-61-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -548.5 778.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.019ex; margin-bottom: -0.139ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-61"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 5 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-62-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -548.5 778.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.019ex; margin-bottom: -0.139ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-62"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></script></span><span> 1 <a href="/topics/engineering/primitive-cell" title="Learn more about primitive cells from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">primitive cells</a> of carbon with a vacuum spacing of 30 Ã…. A </span><em>k</em>-points grid sampling of 4 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-63-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -548.5 778.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.019ex; margin-bottom: -0.139ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-64"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 1 was used for structural relaxation. A sampling of 8 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-65-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; margin-bottom: -0.139ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-65"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 8 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-66-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.808ex" height="1.394ex" viewBox="0 -548.5 778.5 600.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: 0.019ex; margin-bottom: -0.139ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-D7"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-66"><math><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Ã—</mo></mrow></math></script></span> 1 was implemented for the computation of the electronic structure properties. The threshold energy for electronic self-consistency was set to 1 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-67-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#xD7;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; In all computations, a convergence threshold of 0.02&nbsp;eV/Ã…was imposed for the final forces at all <a href="/topics/engineering/geometrical-optimization" title="Learn more about geometrical optimizations from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">geometrical optimizations</a><span>. The vacuum spacing was considered to avoid spurious interactions arising from <a href="/topics/chemistry/van-der-waals-force" title="Learn more about vdW forces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vdW forces</a> among composites.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">In order to obtain insight into the interaction between adsorbed Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and the CM, several possible configurations with different relative positions of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and graphene were considered in the search of the most stable structure with the lowest total energy. Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticle from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticle</a> (NP). It is worth noting that the negative values of the </span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-73-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mtext></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.311ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1855.9 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(681,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-64" x="529" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73" x="1050" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">E</mtext></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-73"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">E</mtext></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span> indicate that the adsorption is favored.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">Charge density difference and charge transfer were also studied. The charge transfer analysis of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP on different CM was performed using Bader population analysis <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/engineering/isosurface" title="Learn more about isosurfaces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">isosurfaces</a> of the charge density difference were mapped, as given by the following equation:</span><span class="display"><span id="e0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" NP.</div></section></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Experimental results</h3><section id="s0045"><h4 id="st045" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.1. Structural and morphological properties of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM nanocomposites</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">The S and Sb doping of the 3D CM, namely S-CM and Sb-CM respectively, was first investigated by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1 (a) and (b) of Supplementary Information</span></span></a><span><span> shows the corresponding elemental mapping images of S-CM and Sb-CM from <a href="/topics/chemistry/field-emission-scanning-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about field emission scanning electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">field emission scanning electron microscopy</a> (FESEM) images. As both heteroatom-doped CM were treated to remove the residual </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a> (see Experimental section), the homogeneous presence of S and Sb elements, suggest their incorporation into the 3D CM. In addition, the heteroatom doping was further analyzed by XPS measurements (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>). These two peaks correspond to the S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C and S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>C <a href="/topics/chemistry/covalent-bond" title="Learn more about covalent bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">covalent bonds</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2(a)</span></span></a>). is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-86"><math><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">Sb</mtext></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">5</mn><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span><span> valence states, which agrees well with that reported for Sb doping of graphene <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoplatelet" title="Learn more about nanoplatelets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoplatelets</a> by mechanochemical ball-milling process </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. Moreover, since Sb3d and O1s signals overlap, the peak located at about 532.5&nbsp;eV can be ascribed to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a><span>. These results confirm the formation of <a href="/topics/materials-science/covalent-bond" title="Learn more about covalent bonds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">covalent bonds</a> after heteroatom doping C and Sb or S bond after the reflux reactions.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> shows the representative morphology of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> deposited by <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal synthesis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal synthesis</a> onto the Sb-CM sample. As illustrated in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>(a) and (b), FESEM and HRTEM images display a cluster of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> (NP) with an average size between 50â€“200&nbsp;nm embedded inside the 3D CM. Whereas </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(c) reveals a lattice fringe pattern with d-spacing of 0.38&nbsp;nm, consistent with the (202) plane of orthorhombic Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> crystals <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. The uniform distribution of the Sb, S and C elements is demonstrated by the elemental mapping images under FESEM observation (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(d)â€“(f)). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a><span> shows the EDS spectra and the corresponding atomic ratio of all nanocomposites. The undoped nanocomposite exhibits an atomic ratio of Sb:S &nbsp;=&nbsp;1:1.51, indicating a stoichiometric <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) and Raman analysis also confirmed the crystal structures of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/heteroatom-doped and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM nanocomposites.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr1.jpg" height="367" alt="" aria-describedby="cn005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size elemental mapping images of representative Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/Sb-CM <a href="/topics/engineering/nanocomposite" title="Learn more about nanocomposite from ScienceDirect's href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(a) exhibit the characteristic sharp peaks corresponding to the orthorhombic phase of <a href="/topics/materials-science/antimony-sulfide" title="Learn more about antimony sulfide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">antimony sulfide</a> (PDF#42â€“1393) </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>. It is worth noting that no other peak related S or Sb crystals are present, revealing the chemical incorporation into the 3D CM network, which agrees well with the XPS and EDS data. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(b) shows the average Raman spectra of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites over an area of 10 x 10 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-87-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BC;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.402ex" height="1.855ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 603.5 798.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BC"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î¼</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-87"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Î¼</mi></mrow></math></script></span><span>m. The <a href="/topics/engineering/raman-peak" title="Learn more about Raman peaks from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman peaks</a> located at low frequency region (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-88-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;lt;</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; The ratios of D- to G-band intensities (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-89-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>I</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%;
