is="true">+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span> state <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. For O1s signal, the peak at 532.3&nbsp;eV is associated to the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bond as mentioned above. Moreover, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(e) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of S2p signal, which can be deconvoluted into two peaks located at 161.2 and 162.5&nbsp;eV attributed to S<sup>2âˆ’</sup> state <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. Such observations are in good agreement with the reported literature <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, suggesting the successful deposition of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> onto 3D CM. More importantly, it is observed that the binding energies of the both Sb3d and S2p signals are shifted to lower energy level when Sb-CM and S-CM were used compared to undoped CM. This phenomenon has been ascribed to a stronger electronic interaction between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and 3D CM <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span>, which is beneficial to enhance the stability of the nanocomposites during sodiation/desodiation process, as well as to improve the <a href="/topics/engineering/electronic-conductivity" title="Learn more about electronic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electronic conductivity</a> at the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/3D <a href="/topics/engineering/matrix-interface" title="Learn more about CM interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CM interface</a>.</span></div></section><section id="s0050"><h4 id="st050" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.2. Electrochemical performance</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075"><span>Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted to evaluate the influence of the <a href="/topics/engineering/interfacial-interaction" title="Learn more about interfacial interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interfacial interaction</a> between Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and heteroatom-doped CM on the electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup> storage. Half coin cells using nanocomposites and sodium metal as electrodes were assembled and tested at scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the voltage range of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V versus Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. The profiles during the first, second and fifth cycle for heteroatom-doped CM are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>. In the first cathodic scan, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites present three distinct peaks centered at 0.71, 0.39 and 0.27&nbsp;V corresponding to the conversion and alloying reaction of S with Na<sup>+</sup> and Sb with Na<sup>+</sup>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr3.jpg" height="746" alt="" aria-describedby="cn015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (756KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (756KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn015"><p id="sp025"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of (a) Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and (b) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM at 0.1&nbsp;mV s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Galvanostatic chargeâ€“discharge profiles of (c) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and (d) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 100&nbsp;mA g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>. (e) Rate capability from 0.1 to 2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and (f) Cycling performance at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> of heteroatom-doped and undoped electrodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(a) and (b), it is evident the change in the peak intensity and location between the first and subsequent cycles, which is assigned to the irreversible <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a><span> interface (SEI) formation. During the anodic scan, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a><span> peaks located at 0.81 and 1.38&nbsp;V belong the reversible <a href="/topics/chemistry/dealloying" title="Learn more about dealloying from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dealloying</a> process and the formation of Sb</span></span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, respectively. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) and (b) also show that the subsequently CV curves for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites are nearly completely overlapped. Conversely, the CV curves for nanocomposites without heteroatom-doped CM (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4(a)</span></span></a>) show overlapping only after the 3rd CV cycle. Thus, the heteroatom doping may contribute to the stability of the nanocomposites during electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup> storage <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>. The galvanostatic chargeâ€“discharge profiles of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM nanocomposites within a potential range of 0.01â€“2.5&nbsp;V at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 100&nbsp;mA g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(c) and (d). The plateaus in the chargeâ€“discharge profiles are consistent with the observed CV redox behavior and previous results <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0315" name="bb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. The initial discharge and charge specific capacities are respectively found to be 1192 and 800 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM, and 1207 and 807 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites. Meanwhile, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a> reveals that the nanocomposite without heteroatom-doped CM delivers an initial discharge and charge specific capacities of only 1108 and 717 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. The corresponding initial Coulombic efficiency for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM (67.1%) and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM (66.9%) are higher than that for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM (64.7%). Notably, anodes based on heteroatom-doped 3D CM show stable perfomance in fewer cycles than those based on Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM. These observations indicate that the modification of the interfacial interaction between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and 3D CM through Sb<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C and S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bonds improve the capacity, coulombic efficiency and the overall stability of the nanocomposites.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">The rate capability of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/heteroatom-doped and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/undoped 3D CM electrodes was assessed for 10 cycles at current densities of 0.1â€“2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(e). Remarkably, the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposite shows superior rate capability than that of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, delivering average specific capacities of 801, 711, 617, 552 and 481 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. In comparison, the initial reversible specific capacity of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM is found to be 709 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> at a <a href="/topics/engineering/low-current-density" title="Learn more about low current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">low current density</a> of 0.1 A g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. It is also visible that as the current density increases, the specific capacity gap between electrodes fabricated with and without heteratom doping is higher. Such performance suggests an enhanced <a href="/topics/chemistry/electron-transport" title="Learn more about electron transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transfer</a> at the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/heteroatom-doped CM interface, as well as an improved conductivity within the nanocomposite after doping <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0320" name="bb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>. It is worth noting that when the rate is returned to 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the reversible rate capability of the electrodes using heteroatom-doped 3D CM is significantly higher compared to the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM nanocomposite. Additionally, cycling performances of the different nanocomposites under a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f. After 150 cycles, the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites exhibit a reversible specific capacity of 608 and 675 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Meanwhile, the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM electrode delivers a reversible specific capacity of only 426 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, demonstrating that heteroatom doping of the CM causes an enhanced electrochemical activity.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090"><span><a href="/topics/chemistry/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) was performed to further reveal the relationship between the interfacial modification by heteroatom doping at the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM interface and electrochemical performance. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5(a)</span></span></a> shows the EIS spectra of the electrodes based on undoped- and doped-CM after 150 cycles at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Each spectrum is composed of a large depressed semicircle at the high-to-medium frequency followed by a sloping line in the low-frequency region. These spectra are in agreement with previous results using Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and graphene as anode for NIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. Therefore, the interface resistance (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-98-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.144ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1784 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6E" x="345" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74" x="946" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-98"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span>) of all electrodes can be considered as the sum of the fitted contribution of SEI resistance (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-99-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.767ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1191.5 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-99"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span><span>) and <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-100-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>ct</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.302ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1421.6 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-63"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74" x="433" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-100"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ct</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span>), <em>i</em>.<em>e</em>. the semicircle at the high-to-medium frequency region <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. The (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-101-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.144ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1784 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-52"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(759,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6E" x="345" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74" x="946" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-101"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">int</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span>) values are found to be 2954, 1248 and 824 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-102-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3A9;</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.678ex" height="2.086ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 722.5 898.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3A9"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-102"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î©</mi></mrow></math></script></span> for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM respectively, which indicates a facilitated interfacial charge transfer within both heteroatom-doped nanocomposites. Moreover, it is possible to elucidate the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetic from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetic</a> in the nanocomposites by plotting the real part resistance (</span><em>Z</em><span>â€™) versus the <a href="/topics/engineering/inverse-square" title="Learn more about inverse square from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inverse square</a> root of the angular frequency (</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-103-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C9;</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>-</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.423ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 2334.7 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C9"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(622,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2212"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(550,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(904,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1258,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï‰</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">-</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-103"><math><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï‰</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">-</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span>) in the low-frequency region (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5(b)</span></span></a>). The lower the slope value, the better the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-process" title="Learn more about diffusion process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion process</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0325" name="bb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a><span>, as observed in the electrodes based on heteroatom-doped nanocomposites. Although an increment in the electrochemical active <a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a> (EASA) could also cause a lower slope, the EASA values were obtained from the typical CV profiles depicted in (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>), using the Randlesâ€“Sevcik equation (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supplementary information</span></span></a>). The EASA values corresponds to approximately 180, 195 and 201&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup> for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM electrodes. The difference is less than 10%, which does not completely account for the differences observed in (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5(b)</span></span></a><span>), and indicates that <a href="/topics/engineering/semiconductor-doping" title="Learn more about doping elements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">doping elements</a> increase both Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> diffusion and the electrochemical activity surface area of the composites. Therefore, these findings evidence that the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-kinetics" title="Learn more about electrochemical kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical kinetics</a> of the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM nanocomposites can be tailored by modifying its interface via heteroatom doping.</div></section></section><section id="s0055"><h3 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Density functional theory results</h3><section id="s0060"><h4 id="st060" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2.1. Structural description of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/graphene and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb- and S-doped graphene</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><span>DFT geometry relaxations were performed in accordance to the methodology described in the Computational details section. As it has previously been stated in the experimental section, the composite materials used for the NIB possess a 3D hierarchy. Particularly, the carbon matrix used in the experiments presents a combined morphology with <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoribbon" title="Learn more about GNR from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GNR</a><span> and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-nanotube" title="Learn more about CNT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CNT</a>. In this sense, theoretical works have been developed to simplify such 3D hierarchy to a 2D hierarchy instead </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0330" name="bb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. That is, MuÃ±iz et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0330" name="bb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a> and Xiong et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span> have shown that a simplified graphene model with its corresponding periodical conditions finely simulates the electronic structure nature of 3D carbon systems. Consequently, a graphene model with its corresponding <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/periodic-boundary-condition" title="Learn more about periodic boundary conditions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">periodic boundary conditions</a> was adopted to study the interactions of carbon with the doping agents and Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100"><span>The geometrical structure of the pristine graphene, S-doped graphene and Sb-doped graphene were optimized. Graphene showed the known hexagonal <a href="/topics/engineering/honeycomb-structure" title="Learn more about honeycomb structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">honeycomb structure</a><span> with a <a href="/topics/engineering/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice constant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice constant</a> of a &nbsp;=&nbsp;b = 2.46 Ã…, c &nbsp;=&nbsp;30 Ã…</span></span>&nbsp;and a C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond length of 1.42 Ã…. After doping with S and Sb on the graphene matrix, as seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>, the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">S and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Sb bond lengths are modified from the original C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond length and the nearest neighbor hexagons were deformed. Such deformation is in close agreement with the experimental results previously disclosed by Raman measurements. This observation is due to the large atomic radii of S and Sb as compared to the C atom. Furthermore, bond lengths of 1.62 Ã…&nbsp;and 1.81 Ã…&nbsp;were found for S-C and Sb-C in S- and Sb-doped graphene, respectively. It is important to highlight that the formation of doping, which was theoretically evidenced, is in agreement with XPS experimental results discussed above. In addition, the models showed no curvature, with a planar geometry instead. The experimentally synthesized nanocomposites were computationally simulated by anchoring a Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> model on the pristine and doped-graphene systems depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>. An Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP was selected as the molecular model, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>, since Kondrat et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0335" name="bb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a> and Caruso et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0340" name="bb0340" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[68]</span></span></a>, based on DFT calculations, showed that such NP fulfills the symmetry of the solid state system. Moreover, the reduced model finely reproduces all electronic structure properties observed for the solid-state system.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr4.jpg" height="412" alt="" aria-describedby="cn020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (244KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (244KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn020"><p id="sp030"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. The optimized geometry structures of (a) pristine graphene, (b) S-doped graphene and (c) Sb-doped graphene. The S, C and Sb atoms are depicted in yellow, grey and purple balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The XRD experimental results revealed that the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> system indeed, showed the predominant orthorhombic phase, as revealed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a> and the (PDF#42â€“1393) data card. Consequently, since the predominant phase obeys the symmetry of the simplified molecular model of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>, the NP system was implemented in the subsequent computations to reduce computing time. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a> depicts three surface models showing different possible configurations with diverse relative positions of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP with respect to graphene.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0110">Moreover, analogous calculations were performed for the doped-graphene model systems namely, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM. Three attacks of the NP on graphene were considered, <em>i</em>.<em>e</em>. model <strong>1</strong>, model <strong>2</strong> and model <strong>3</strong><span> configurations with respect to the graphene plane. The same principle was applied for the Sb-doped and S-doped carbon matrices. Furthermore, the configurations were defined with both, vertical and horizontal arrangements with respect to the <a href="/topics/engineering/graphene-sheet" title="Learn more about graphene sheet from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene sheet</a>. Model </span><strong>1</strong> corresponds to the horizontal(H) configuration (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7(a)</span></span></a>). In such configuration, the NP interacts in parallel planes with the graphene systems. Whilst, in model <strong>2</strong> and model <strong>3</strong>, the NP was located in vertical positions with respect to the graphene plane. The graphene sheet interacted with the Sb (model <strong>2</strong>) and S (model <strong>3</strong>) atoms of the NP at the center of a carbon ring (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7(b) and (c)</span></span></a>). The computations showed that the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP presented the lowest-energy configuration with respect to the pristine graphene (Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM) in the interaction presented in model <strong>1</strong> (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a)). The same notation (model <strong>1</strong>, model <strong>2</strong>, and model <strong>3</strong>) was applied for the doped-graphene cases; namely, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM. The lowest-energy orientations for Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems corresponded to the configuration in which the NP was adsorbed at the position illustrated in model <strong>2</strong>. The full optimizations resulted in a hexagon distorted matrix at the peripheral of the S and Sb doped-atoms, as it is depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(b) and (c).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr5.jpg" height="637" alt="" aria-describedby="cn025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (342KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (342KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn025"><p id="sp035"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <span>Top and side views of structures with the lowest <a href="/topics/chemistry/adsorption-energy" title="Learn more about adsorption energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">adsorption energy</a> (PBE&nbsp;+&nbsp;vdW) according to the notation given in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>: (a) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM (model <strong>1</strong>), (b) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM (model <strong>2</strong>) and (c) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM (<strong>model 2</strong>). The S, C and Sb atoms are represented by yellow, grey and purple balls, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Additionally, before the optimization of the composite, the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP presented a molecular structure as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>, with an average bond length of 2.45 Ã… for Sb-S. After full optimization of the composite, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a> shows the possible conformations of the NP and the average bond distance of S-Sb atoms in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems. Such distances are given in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0005" name="bt0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>. The original orthorhombic symmetry of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP was modified.</div><div class="tables colsep-0 frame-topbot rowsep-0" id="t0005"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn035"><p id="sp045"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. The C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">S, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Sb bond lengths of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM distorted structures for model 1 (m1), model 2 (m2) and model 3 (m3), respectively. The average S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Sb bond lengths in the same composite materials for m1, m2 and m3, as seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="valign-top"><td m3</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM</td><td class="align-center">1.42</td><td class="align-center">1.42 1.42 1.42</td><td class="align-center">2.452 2.646 2.456</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM</td><td class="align-center">1.62</td><td class="align-center">1.74 1.74 1.74</td><td class="align-center">2.534 2.456 2.456</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM</td><td class="align-center">1.81</td><td class="align-center">2.21 2.11 2.17</td><td class="align-center">2.39 2.51 2.464</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0120"><span>The NP in the <a href="/topics/materials-science/complex-system" title="Learn more about composite systems from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composite systems</a> repealed the doped Sb and S atoms at the graphene sheet. This changed the Sb</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C and S<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond distances, and consequently altered the curvature of the plane to induce a deviation with respect to the <em>z</em>-axis. The calculated adsorption energies for the composite materials are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>. The structure with the lowest adsorption energy was Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM, resulting in the most stable interaction. As previously stated, the stabilization of the composite is in agreement with our experimental observation evidenced with the binding energy measurements. The distortion theoretically evidenced was quantified as the deviation of the average positions of Sb and S atoms in the hexagon for both systems Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM. That is, for model <strong>1</strong> (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>), the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Sb, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">S bond length are 1.74 Ã… and 2.21 Ã…, respectively. With respect to Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems, the large deviations evidenced the anchoring of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP on the Sb-doped and S-doped graphene surfaces. As previously suggested by the experiment, this effect could enhance the capacity and diffusion on the <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> electrode.</span></div><div class="tables colsep-0 frame-topbot rowsep-0" id="t0010"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn040"><p id="sp050"><span class="label">Table 2</span>. The adsorption energy (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-105-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mtext></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.311ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1855.9 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(681,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-64" x="529" y="0"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73" x="1050" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">E</mtext></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-105"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">E</mtext></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">ads</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math></script></span>) of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> over carbon matrix and on S- and Sb- doped graphene matrix for model 1 (m1), model 2 (m2) and model 3 (m3), respectively. The effective charges were calculated by means of the Bader method. Positive sign indicate transfer from the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP to the surface, while negative sign denotes electron transfer in the opposite direction.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="valign-top"><th scope="col" class="align-left">Materials</th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-65"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(745,0)"><use class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" class="align-center">m1 m2 m3</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">m1 m2 m3</th><td scope="col" class="align-center"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.072 âˆ’0.23 âˆ’0.10</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.63 âˆ’0.32 âˆ’0.31</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.0112</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’6.79 âˆ’6.91 âˆ’6.87</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’7.31 âˆ’7.41 âˆ’7.23</td><td class="align-center">+0.004</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’1.86 âˆ’2.01 âˆ’1.90</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’2.32 âˆ’2.34 âˆ’2.12</td><td class="align-center">+0.0925</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">The orientations for the composite materials Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM (model <strong>1</strong>) and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM (model <strong>2</strong>) are the lowest-energy configurations with binding energies amounting to âˆ’0.63&nbsp;eV and âˆ’2.34&nbsp;eV (with vdW contribution), respectively (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>). This result is in agreement with previous results of Xiong et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Finally, it is worth to mention that the differences between the calculated adsorption energies performed with PBE and PBE-vdW are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>. The vdW contribution is particularly important in such 2D systems, resulting in more stable composite materials.</div></section><section id="s0065"><h4 id="st065" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2.2. Charge density difference</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130"><span>The <a href="/topics/engineering/isosurface" title="Learn more about isosurfaces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">isosurfaces</a> obtained with the aid of Eq. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a> are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(a)-(c)</span></span></a>. The anchoring of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP certainly modified the topology in the CM, Sb-CM and S-CM systems. The yellow regions on the isosurfaces represent charge depletion at that volume, while the blue regions are zones in which the charge is accumulated. As it is shown in the figures, the NP transferred a portion of their electronic charge to the sheets. The charge transfer is dependent on the doping element. In this case, Sb and S atoms interact with the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP by an <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrostatic-interaction" title="Learn more about electrostatic interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic interaction</a><span>. Additionally, a <a href="/topics/chemistry/charge-transfer-interaction" title="Learn more about charge transfer interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer interaction</a> was induced among the atoms of the NP, and the Sb and S atoms in the doped systems.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The Bader charge analysis (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>) indicated that the positive values are related to an electronic charge excess that comes from the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP to the graphene and doped-graphene sheet in all systems. The NP depleted a fractional charge equal to 0.0925 and 0.004 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-109-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.377ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 1023.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-65"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(745,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-109"><math><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<em>e</em> is the elementary charge) in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems, respectively. Otherwise, the NP accumulated a fractional charge amounting to 0.011 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-110-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.377ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 1023.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-65"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(745,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-110"><math><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></script></span> in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, which may be due to their polarized electronic states. Remarkable charge rearrangement occurs around the neighboring atoms of the CM and the S and Sb atoms in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposite systems. The Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM composite system showed a simultaneous accumulation and depletion of the charge (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(a)</span></span></a><span>), which could be associated to an effective recombination of electrons and holes in such a system as well as affecting the charge carriers transport. This property would limit the extraction of electrons from the graphene sheet to the electrolyte if the nanocomposite systems were the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> in an energy storage device. Moreover, in the charge density isosurfaces in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(b) and (c)</span></span></a>, the charge transfer character was improved for the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM composite systems. That is, the charge transfer is allowed from the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP to the Sb- and S-doped CM, inducing a negative charge excess, particularly accumulated on the sheet (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7(b) and (c)</span></span></a>). Moreover, the depletion (yellow) of electronic charge was located in the NP and at the distorted and curved hexagons, in which the Sb and S centers were present.</div></section><section id="s0070"><h4 id="st070" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2.3. Electronic structure properties</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">The effect of the adsorption of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP at CM, S-CM and Sb-CM was assessed in terms of the electronic structure properties. The total <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (DOS) and partial density of states (PDOS) of each system were calculated and presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">S10</span></span></a><span>, respectively. Upon adsorption, the NP introduced additional electronic states at the <a href="/topics/chemistry/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a><span>, which induced a semi-metallic nature compared to the pristine, Sb- and S-doped graphene. The <a href="/topics/engineering/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a> of Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/Sb-CM systems was slightly shifted to the <a href="/topics/engineering/valence-band" title="Learn more about valence band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">valence band</a>, while the Fermi level of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM system approached the <a href="/topics/engineering/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a>, evidencing the </span><em>n</em>-type character of the material. Accordingly, a possible conductivity would be envisaged relative to the doping with Sb and S atoms in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6.jpg" height="212" alt="" aria-describedby="cn030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (325KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (325KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn030"><p id="sp040"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>Total <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> of (a) Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, (b) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM and (c) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM with pristine graphene. The scale of left <em>y</em>-axis corresponds to the total DOS.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The PDOS of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM system are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(a)</span></span></a>, in which the 2<em>p</em>-C orbitals overlapped with the 3<em>p</em><span>-S orbitals, forming a covalent-type hybridization. A small overlap was observed among the former atoms and the 5p-orbitals of the Sb atom in the NP, which indicates the formation of an <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-bonding" title="Learn more about ionic bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic bonding</a> between the NP and the S/C atoms in this system. The PDOS of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(b)</span></span></a>, in which the 5p-Sb orbitals of the NP and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-111-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.332ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1004 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(500,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-111"><math><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></script></span>-S orbitals overlapped with <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-112-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.332ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1004 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(500,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-112"><math><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></script></span>-C orbitals of the CM, evidencing a covalent-type hybridization at the interface (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(b)</span></span></a>). The 5p-Sb orbitals provided additional states at the Fermi level, giving rise to the new electronic states in the DOS profile. The covalent interaction makes a stronger bonding when it is adsorbed at the graphene sheet, despite the bonding among Sb and S atoms is dominated by an ionic interaction into the NP. This result agrees with the large adsorption energy listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a> for system Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM. Furthermore, the nature of the hybridization among C and S and the weak anionic interaction with Sb (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(a)</span></span></a>), is in agreement with the low adsorption energy reported in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a> for the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM system. The strong binding of the NP with the doping atoms in graphene, increases its metallic-like character. This behavior could be associated to a possible improvement in the conductivity of the composite systems under study.</div></section></section></section><section id="s0075"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In summary, nanocomposite systems consisting of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> embedded in Sb- and S-doped CM were successfully obtained. Experimental and theoretical studies demonstrated that by modifying the interfacial interaction between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and CM, the electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup> storage of the nanocomposite electrodes can be substantially improved. The Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites exhibited a reversible specific capacity of 608 and 675 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Such electrochemical performances are higher than that of electrode based on undoped nanocomposite, which delivered only a reversible specific capacity of 426 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. DFT was used to analyze the adsorption energy, charge density difference and electronic structure properties of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM <a href="/topics/materials-science/complex-system" title="Learn more about composite systems from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composite systems</a>. The charge density difference analysis revealed that the depletion of charges was present in the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP and the accumulation of charges was present at the interfaces, with a charge exchange between the NP and the three CM under study. The charge transfer was improved in the both heteroatom doped-CM due to the presence of S and Sb <a href="/topics/materials-science/semiconductor-doping" title="Learn more about doping elements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">doping elements</a>. The analysis of DOS and PDOS indicated that new occupied states have been found in the density of states with a possible improvement in the conductivity of the composite systems. Finally, the combined DFT and experimental results revealed that tailoring the heteroatom-doped carbon matrix with Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP led to stable nanocomposites and improved charge density transfer for outstanding cycling stability. Both approaches may aid in the <em>in silico</em> design of novel composite materials intended to be implemented in NIBs.</div></section><section id="s0090"><h2 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><strong>Oscar A. Jaramillo-Quintero:</strong> Conceptualization, Investigation, Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Royer ValentÃ­n Barrera-Peralta:</strong> Investigation, Visualization, Validation. <strong>Abdel Ghafour El Hachimi:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Alfredo GuillÃ©n-L</strong>Ã³<strong>pez:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Obed PÃ©rez:</strong> Validation, Formal analysis. <strong>Edilso Reguera:</strong> Resources, Validation. <strong>Marina Elizabeth Rinc</strong>Ã³<strong>n:</strong> Funding acquisition, Resources, Writing - review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Jes</strong>Ãº<strong>s Mu</strong>Ã±<strong>iz:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition, Resources, Formal analysis.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st115" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">The authors would like to acknowledge the financial support given by Fondo Sectorial de InvestigaciÃ³n para la EducaciÃ³n-CONACYT under Project No. A1-S-13294 and A1-S-15336, and DGAPA (DirecciÃ³n General de Asuntos del Personal AcadÃ©mico) under Project No. PAPIIT-IN109319, PAPIIT-IN103718 and PAPIIT-IA102820. u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor Caruso, M.R. Filip, F. Giustino</div><div id="ref-id-h0340" class="title text-m">Excitons in one-dimensional van der Waals materials: Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> nanoribbons</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Phys. Rev. B, 92 (2015), p. 125134</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.92.125134" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0340"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Excitons%20in%20one-dimensional%20van%20der%20Waals%20materials%3A%20Sb2S3%20nanoribbons&amp;publication_year=2015&amp;author=F.%20Caruso&amp;author=M.R.%20Filip&amp;author=F.%20Giustino"
