class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" class="align-center">m1 m2 m3</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">m1 m2 m3</th><td scope="col" class="align-center"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.072 âˆ’0.23 âˆ’0.10</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.63 âˆ’0.32 âˆ’0.31</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’0.0112</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’6.79 âˆ’6.91 âˆ’6.87</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’7.31 âˆ’7.41 âˆ’7.23</td><td class="align-center">+0.004</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’1.86 âˆ’2.01 âˆ’1.90</td><td class="align-center">âˆ’2.32 âˆ’2.34 âˆ’2.12</td><td class="align-center">+0.0925</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">The orientations for the composite materials Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM (model <strong>1</strong>) and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM (model <strong>2</strong>) are the lowest-energy configurations with binding energies amounting to âˆ’0.63&nbsp;eV and âˆ’2.34&nbsp;eV (with vdW contribution), respectively (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>). This result is in agreement with previous results of Xiong et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Finally, it is worth to mention that the differences between the calculated adsorption energies performed with PBE and PBE-vdW are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>. The vdW contribution is particularly important in such 2D systems, resulting in more stable composite materials.</div></section><section id="s0065"><h4 id="st065" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2.2. Charge density difference</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130"><span>The <a href="/topics/engineering/isosurface" title="Learn more about isosurfaces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">isosurfaces</a> obtained with the aid of Eq. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a> are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(a)-(c)</span></span></a>. The anchoring of the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP certainly modified the topology in the CM, Sb-CM and S-CM systems. The yellow regions on the isosurfaces represent charge depletion at that volume, while the blue regions are zones in which the charge is accumulated. As it is shown in the figures, the NP transferred a portion of their electronic charge to the sheets. The charge transfer is dependent on the doping element. In this case, Sb and S atoms interact with the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP by an <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrostatic-interaction" title="Learn more about electrostatic interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrostatic interaction</a><span>. Additionally, a <a href="/topics/chemistry/charge-transfer-interaction" title="Learn more about charge transfer interaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer interaction</a> was induced among the atoms of the NP, and the Sb and S atoms in the doped systems.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The Bader charge analysis (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>) indicated that the positive values are related to an electronic charge excess that comes from the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP to the graphene and doped-graphene sheet in all systems. The NP depleted a fractional charge equal to 0.0925 and 0.004 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-109-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.377ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 1023.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-65"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(745,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-109"><math><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></script></span> (<em>e</em> is the elementary charge) in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems, respectively. Otherwise, the NP accumulated a fractional charge amounting to 0.011 <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-110-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>e</mi><mo stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>|</mo></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.377ex" height="2.779ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 1023.5 1196.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(278,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-65"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(745,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-7C"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-110"><math><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo><mi is="true">e</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">|</mo></mrow></math></script></span> in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, which may be due to their polarized electronic states. Remarkable charge rearrangement occurs around the neighboring atoms of the CM and the S and Sb atoms in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposite systems. The Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM composite system showed a simultaneous accumulation and depletion of the charge (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(a)</span></span></a><span>), which could be associated to an effective recombination of electrons and holes in such a system as well as affecting the charge carriers transport. This property would limit the extraction of electrons from the graphene sheet to the electrolyte if the nanocomposite systems were the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> in an energy storage device. Moreover, in the charge density isosurfaces in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9(b) and (c)</span></span></a>, the charge transfer character was improved for the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM composite systems. That is, the charge transfer is allowed from the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP to the Sb- and S-doped CM, inducing a negative charge excess, particularly accumulated on the sheet (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7(b) and (c)</span></span></a>). Moreover, the depletion (yellow) of electronic charge was located in the NP and at the distorted and curved hexagons, in which the Sb and S centers were present.</div></section><section id="s0070"><h4 id="st070" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2.3. Electronic structure properties</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">The effect of the adsorption of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP at CM, S-CM and Sb-CM was assessed in terms of the electronic structure properties. The total <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> (DOS) and partial density of states (PDOS) of each system were calculated and presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">S10</span></span></a><span>, respectively. Upon adsorption, the NP introduced additional electronic states at the <a href="/topics/chemistry/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a><span>, which induced a semi-metallic nature compared to the pristine, Sb- and S-doped graphene. The <a href="/topics/engineering/fermi-level" title="Learn more about Fermi level from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fermi level</a> of Sb</span></span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/Sb-CM systems was slightly shifted to the <a href="/topics/engineering/valence-band" title="Learn more about valence band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">valence band</a>, while the Fermi level of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM system approached the <a href="/topics/engineering/conduction-band" title="Learn more about conduction band from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">conduction band</a>, evidencing the </span><em>n</em>-type character of the material. Accordingly, a possible conductivity would be envisaged relative to the doping with Sb and S atoms in Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM systems.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6.jpg" height="212" alt="" aria-describedby="cn030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (325KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (325KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn030"><p id="sp040"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>Total <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-of-states" title="Learn more about density of states from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">density of states</a> of (a) Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, (b) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM and (c) Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM with pristine graphene. The scale of left <em>y</em>-axis corresponds to the total DOS.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">The PDOS of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM system are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(a)</span></span></a>, in which the 2<em>p</em>-C orbitals overlapped with the 3<em>p</em><span>-S orbitals, forming a covalent-type hybridization. A small overlap was observed among the former atoms and the 5p-orbitals of the Sb atom in the NP, which indicates the formation of an <a href="/topics/materials-science/ionic-bonding" title="Learn more about ionic bonding from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic bonding</a> between the NP and the S/C atoms in this system. The PDOS of Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM are depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(b)</span></span></a>, in which the 5p-Sb orbitals of the NP and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-111-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.332ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1004 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(500,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-111"><math><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></script></span>-S orbitals overlapped with <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-112-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>p</mi></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="2.332ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1004 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(500,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-70"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-112"><math><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><mi is="true">p</mi></mrow></math></script></span>-C orbitals of the CM, evidencing a covalent-type hybridization at the interface (see <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(b)</span></span></a>). The 5p-Sb orbitals provided additional states at the Fermi level, giving rise to the new electronic states in the DOS profile. The covalent interaction makes a stronger bonding when it is adsorbed at the graphene sheet, despite the bonding among Sb and S atoms is dominated by an ionic interaction into the NP. This result agrees with the large adsorption energy listed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a> for system Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM. Furthermore, the nature of the hybridization among C and S and the weak anionic interaction with Sb (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0085" name="bs0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10(a)</span></span></a>), is in agreement with the low adsorption energy reported in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#t0010" name="bt0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="t0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a> for the Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM system. The strong binding of the NP with the doping atoms in graphene, increases its metallic-like character. This behavior could be associated to a possible improvement in the conductivity of the composite systems under study.</div></section></section></section><section id="s0075"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In summary, nanocomposite systems consisting of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> embedded in Sb- and S-doped CM were successfully obtained. Experimental and theoretical studies demonstrated that by modifying the interfacial interaction between Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> and CM, the electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup> storage of the nanocomposite electrodes can be substantially improved. The Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/S-CM nanocomposites exhibited a reversible specific capacity of 608 and 675 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a current density of 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Such electrochemical performances are higher than that of electrode based on undoped nanocomposite, which delivered only a reversible specific capacity of 426 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. DFT was used to analyze the adsorption energy, charge density difference and electronic structure properties of Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/CM, Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub>/Sb-CM and Sb<sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span>/S-CM <a href="/topics/materials-science/complex-system" title="Learn more about composite systems from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composite systems</a>. The charge density difference analysis revealed that the depletion of charges was present in the Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub><span> NP and the accumulation of charges was present at the interfaces, with a charge exchange between the NP and the three CM under study. The charge transfer was improved in the both heteroatom doped-CM due to the presence of S and Sb <a href="/topics/materials-science/semiconductor-doping" title="Learn more about doping elements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">doping elements</a>. The analysis of DOS and PDOS indicated that new occupied states have been found in the density of states with a possible improvement in the conductivity of the composite systems. Finally, the combined DFT and experimental results revealed that tailoring the heteroatom-doped carbon matrix with Sb</span><sub>2</sub>S<sub>3</sub> NP led to stable nanocomposites and improved charge density transfer for outstanding cycling stability. Both approaches may aid in the <em>in silico</em> design of novel composite materials intended to be implemented in NIBs.</div></section><section id="s0090"><h2 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155"><strong>Oscar A. Jaramillo-Quintero:</strong> Conceptualization, Investigation, Methodology, Formal analysis, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Royer ValentÃ­n Barrera-Peralta:</strong> Investigation, Visualization, Validation. <strong>Abdel Ghafour El Hachimi:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Alfredo GuillÃ©n-L</strong>Ã³<strong>pez:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing. <strong>Obed PÃ©rez:</strong> Validation, Formal analysis. <strong>Edilso Reguera:</strong> Resources, Validation. <strong>Marina Elizabeth Rinc</strong>Ã³<strong>n:</strong> Funding acquisition, Resources, Writing - review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Jes</strong>Ãº<strong>s Mu</strong>Ã±<strong>iz:</strong> Software, Writing - original draft, Writing - review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition, Resources, Formal analysis.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st115" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">The authors would like to acknowledge the financial support given by Fondo Sectorial de InvestigaciÃ³n para la EducaciÃ³n-CONACYT under Project No. A1-S-13294 and A1-S-15336, and DGAPA (DirecciÃ³n General de Asuntos del Personal AcadÃ©mico) under Project No. PAPIIT-IN109319, PAPIIT-IN103718 and PAPIIT-IA102820. A.G.E.H. and A.G.L. want to acknowledge the postdoctoral grant and PhD. scholarship; respectively, provided by CONACYT with No. A1-S-13294 and A1-S-15336, respectively. J.M. wants to acknowledge the support given by the computational infrastructure provided by Laboratorio Nacional de ConversiÃ³n y Almacenamiento de EnergÃ­a (CONACYT) under project No. 270810, and the Supercomputing Department of Universidad Nacional AutÃ³noma de MÃ©xico for the computing resources under Project No. LANCAD-UNAM-DGTIC-370, and LANCAD-UNAM-DGTIC-310. We also are grateful to M. L. RamÃ³n, O. Gomez-Daza, R. MorÃ¡n Elvira, and J. Campos for technical assistance.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0085"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Supplementary data</h2><span class="download-all-supplemental-data"><span class="article-attachment"><iframe title="download_all" name="download_all" class="u-hide"></iframe><form method="post" action="/sdfe/pdf/download/S0021979720313679/attachments" target="download_all"><input name="eids" type="hidden" value="1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-mmc1.xml"><input name="eids" type="hidden" value="1-s2.0-S0021979720313679-mmc2.pdf"><button class="button-link download-all-button u-font-sans button-link-primary button-link-icon-left" type="submit"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 98 128" height="20" class="icon icon-download"><path d="M77.38 56.18l-6.6-7.06L54 66.36V26H44v40.34L26.28 49.1l-7.3 7.08 29.2 29.32 29.2-29.32M88 74v20H10V74H0v30h98V74H88"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><span class="download-all-title">Download all </span>supplementary files<span class="u-show-inline-from-sm"> included with this article</span></span></span></button></form><a class="anchor help-link u-font-sans u-margin-s-left anchor-primary anchor-has-colored-icon anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://service.elsevier.com/app/answers/detail/a_id/19286/supporthub/sciencedirect/" target="_blank" title="Whatâ€™s this? class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (32)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724004636"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Catalytic chemistry inspired hollow carbon nanofibers loaded with NiS/Ni as high-performance and safe Li&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; reservoir</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Transition metal sulfides (TMSs) based anodes hold a very broad application prospect in lithium ion batteries (LIBs). In this work, the catalytic effect of metallic nickel at high temperature was used to generate hollow carbon nanofibers loaded with NiS and Ni (denoted as NiS/Ni@HCNF). The heteroatoms doped carbon fibers buffer the huge volumetric change of NiS during the discharge/charge process, and enhance the ion transport efficiency and electrical conductivity. In addition, the high specific surface area brought by the hollow carbon nanofibers can accelerate the electrolyte penetration and speed up the transport of ions as well as electrons. When used as anode of half cell, this electrode gives 958.5 and 612.9 mAh/g after running 1000 cycles under 1 and 2 A/g, showing the extremely-low attenuation rates of 0.0483&nbsp;% per cycle and 0.0643&nbsp;% per cycle, respectively. Impressively, NCM//NiS/Ni@HCNF battery shows the discharge capacity of 187.6 mAh/g at 1st cycle. Regarding the next 100 cycles, the relatively-high discharge capacities (&gt;110 mAh/g) and coulombic efficiency (CE) values (&gt;96&nbsp;%) are discerned. It is noted that the usage of NiS/Ni@HCNF electrode improves the activation energy for thermal runaway, corroborating the elevated thermal safety of battery.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1001841721004654"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">SbPS&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;: A novel anode for high-performance sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2022, Chinese Chemical Letters</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009">With the in-depth research of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), the development of novel sodium-ion anode material has become a top priority. In this work, tube cluster-shaped SbPS<sub>4</sub> was synthesized by a high-temperature solid phase reaction. Then the typical short tubular ternary thiophosphate SbPS<sub>4</sub> compounded with graphene oxide (SbPS<sub>4</sub>/GO) was successfully synthesized after ultrasonication and freeze-drying. SbPS<sub>4</sub> shows a high theoretical specific capacity (1335&nbsp;mAh/g) according to the conversion-alloying dual mechanisms. The unique short tube inserted in the spongy graphene structure of SbPS<sub>4</sub>/GO results in boosting the Na ions transport and alleviating the huge volume change in the charging and discharging processes, improving the sodium storage performance. Consequently, the tubular SbPS<sub>4</sub> compounded with 10% GO provides an outstanding capacity of 359.58&nbsp;mAh/g at 500&nbsp;mA/g. The result indicates that SbPS<sub>4</sub>/GO anode has a promising application potential for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979721003404"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Facile in-situ synthesis of heazlewoodite on nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide for enhanced sodium storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2021, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), featuring high resource abundance and similar working mechanism with LIBs, have gained renewed attention [10â€“12]. Unfortunately, the large ionic radius and high ionization potential impede the dynamics of Na+, thus leading to sluggish reaction kinetics [13â€“16]. To realize reversible insertion/desertion of Na+ into/from host materials, advanced electrode materials with rich active sites and large interstitial space are imperative [6â€“8].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Nickel sulfide based anode materials, featuring rich types, high specific capacities and favorable conversion kinetics, have been proved to be promisingly applied in high-performance sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Unfortunately, the poor electronic/ionic conductivity, together with the structure change induced degraded capacity upon cycling, restricts their further development. In this work, heazlewoodite nanoparticles decorated on nitrogen doped reduced graphene oxide (Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>/NrGO) were fabricated <em>via</em> a facile combined approach with freeze-drying and subsequent in-situ sulfidation. In the obtained hybrid structure, the synergistic effect between Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub> and NrGO endows the composite with highly conductive pathways, thus accelerating the charge transfer. Benefitting from the buffering matrix offered by NrGO as well as the tight combination between Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub> and NrGO, this novel Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub>/NrGO demonstrates satisfying sodium storage performance, with a stable reversible capacity of 299.2 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> up to 100 cycles (0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 76.8%. Importantly, the rational structure design and synthesis method, as well as the insights on the improved electrochemical performance reported in this work, should be helpful for the development of new-type host materials with high performance for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.3c02892" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advanced Anode Materials for Rechargeable Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2023, ACS Nano</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1039/d1ta10540j" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1D confined materials synthesized via a coating method for thermal catalysis and energy storage applications</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2022, Journal of Materials Chemistry A</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsami.2c05262" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Double-Enhanced Coreâˆ’Shellâˆ’Shell Sb&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;S&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;/Sb@TiO&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;@C Nanorod Composites for Lithium- and Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2022, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article3-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S092583882033382X" title="Canted ferrimagnetism in the distorted double perovskite La3Mn2NbO9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Canted ferrimagnetism in the distorted double perovskite La<sub>3</sub>Mn<sub>2</sub>NbO<sub>9</sub></span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Alloys and Compounds, Volume 854, 2021, Article 157018</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Diana M.</span> <span>Arciniegas Jaimes</span>, â€¦, <span>RaÃºl E.</span> <span>Carbonio</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon"     function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,

      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
